section.title: Understand collections of items
section.paragraph: Where an item can contain more than one child item (for example, more than one Variable in a Component, more than one Units item in a Model, etc) the processes for curating that collection follow the patterns outlined below.
NB: All of this explanation uses “thing” in place of the specific type of item (component, variable etc).
NB: This section explains the basic rationale of the collections. For practical information about how they are used, please see the Viewing a model and Editing a model pages.

section.title: Count things
section.paragraph: Generic counting functions will return the number of child items using the thingCount() function to get the number of thing children. For example, unitsCount() returns the number of Units items in a Model. This is useful when iterating through a collection or before using an index to access one of its members.

section.title: Get a thing
section.paragraph: Pointers to items within a collection can be retrieved in two ways: by getting or by taking. The first does not affect the collection, and returns a pointer to the item: this is accomplished using the thing function.
There are two overloaded arguments for the get functionality:

list_item.paragraph: thing(i) returns a pointer to the thing at the i-th index position; and
thing("myThingName") returns a pointer to the thing named “myThingName”.

section.paragraph: Note that in this case the retrieval of the thing does not alter it, and neither does it alter the parent which owns it.

section.title: Add a thing
section.paragraph: To add to a collection use the addThing functionality. The basic form of adding is by symbol: addThing(thingToAdd) which will append the pointer to thingToAdd to the collection. Special cases of this are:

list_item.paragraph: The addComponent function will return a boolean variable telling you whether the operation was successful or not. In situations where the component has already been included in the collection, is present in another collection, or is not found, this operation will return false. Other add functions do not return any value.
The addUnit function has many overloaded argument lists. Please refer to the full API addUnit reference for details.

section.title: Remove one thing
section.paragraph: To remove an item from the collection and detach its parent without returning a pointer to that item, use the removeThing functions.

container.paragraph: Because the collections are stored as a group of smart pointers, if no references exist to the item then its contents will also be deleted. If other references do exist, the parent pointer will be detached, but they won’t otherwise be affected.

section.title: Remove all the things
section.paragraph: In addition to the removal of specific items from a collection as above, you can also clear the entire collection using the removeAllThings functions.

section.title: Take a thing
section.paragraph: The takeThing functions combine a little of the remove and a little of the get functionality. It will return a pointer to the item (like the get thing functionality above), but it will also remove the item from the collection (like removeThing), updating both the collection as well as the item’s parent. The item is thus detached from its parent, and “taken” by the returned pointer.
Examples are shown for C++ and Python below.

# Consider the case where we already have a model containing a component named "myComponent" at index 0.
# Case 1: Use the get and remove functionality together. component = model.component(0) # Get either by index, component = model.component("componentName") # or by name.
was_removed = model.removeComponent(0) # Remove either by index, was_removed = model.removeComponent("componentName") # by name, was_removed = model.removeComponent(component) # or by symbol.
# At this point, the model's components collection no longer contains the component, and the component # pointer has no parent.
# Case 2: Use the take functionality. component = model.takeComponent(0) # Take either by index, component = model.takeComponent("myComponent") # or by name.
# At this point, we have the same outcome as in Case 1 above. The model's component collection no # longer contains the component, and the component itself has no parent.
# Case 3: A cautionary tale using remove without get. i_am_a_bool_not_a_component = model.removeComponent(0) # Remove either by index, name or symbol as above.
# In the situation where no other reference to the component exists (ie: we did not "get" it as in Case 1), # the model's collection will no longer contain the component AND the entire contents of that component # will be permanently deleted.

section.title: Replace a thing
section.paragraph: Within the Model and Component items are replaceUnits and replaceComponent functions respectively. Their operation is straightforward: a position within the collection is specified (either using an index, or the name of an existing item in the collection), and a replacement item is supplied. The replacement item overwrites what was previously stored at the position in the collection. In addition, the replaceComponent takes an optional boolean argument indicating whether to search the encapsulated children for the item, if specified by name. By default this is set to true. For more information about replacement, please see the API documentation for Model and Component items directly.

container.paragraph: Note that these only operate on collections of items. That is:

list_item.paragraph: the collections of Units, Component and ImportSource items in a parent Model;
the encapsulated child Component, Reset or Variable items in a parent Component;
the child Unit items in a parent Units item;
the imported Units or Component items in a parent ImportSource; and
the added Model items in an Importer instance.
